revision.text:
{{pp-pc1}} {{Use mdy dates|date=January 2015}} {{Infobox person | name = Jenny McCarthy | othername = Jenny Wahlberg{{cite web|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/entertainment/tv/ct-jenny-mccarthy-donnie-wahlberg-show-20160317-story.html|title=Jenny McCarthy shows off her Donnie tattoos, announces name change|first=Tracy|last=Swartz|date=|website=chicagotribune.com|accessdate=May 17, 2017}} | image = Jenny McCarthy at E3 2006.jpg | imagesize = | alt = McCarthy smiling and wearing a headset microphone | caption = McCarthy in May 2006 | birth_name = Jennifer Ann McCarthy | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|mf=yes|1972|11|1}} | birth_place = [[Evergreen Park, Illinois]], U.S. | occupation = Actress, model, television host, author, activist, screenwriter | alma_mater = [[Southern Illinois University]] | yearsactive = 1993–present | spouse = {{Plain list| *{{Marriage|[[John Asher]]
|1999|2005|end=div}} *{{Marriage|[[Donnie Wahlberg]]
|2014}} }} | domesticpartner = [[Jim Carrey]] (2005–2010) | children = 1 | relatives = {{Plain list| *[[Joanne McCarthy]] (sister) *[[Melissa McCarthy]] (cousin) }} | website = | television = {{Plainlist| * {{nowrap|[[The Jenny McCarthy Show (1997)|''The Jenny McCarthy Show'' (1997)]]}} * ''[[Jenny (TV series)|Jenny]]'' * {{nowrap|[[The Jenny McCarthy Show (2013)|''The Jenny McCarthy Show'' (2013)]]}} * ''[[Donnie Loves Jenny]]'' }} }} '''Jennifer Ann McCarthy''' (born November 1, 1972),{{cite web|url=http://wekinglypigs.com/cgi-bin/nand/search/pmstat?browse=%3A%3ACONFIG%3A%3Adatebrowse&key=1993&limit=0|title=Playmate listing|accessdate=March 8, 2009}}{{cite news|url=http://www.eonline.com/celebrities/profile/index.jsp?uuid=f1be2dea-9225-4813-a53c-2e14660ffbd3 |title=Jenny McCarthy Profile|work= [[E!]] Online|accessdate= 2007-09-19}} credited as '''Jenny McCarthy''' and '''Jenny Wahlberg''', is an American anti-vaccine activist, actress, model, television host, author, and screenwriter. She began her career in 1993 as a [[Glamour photography|nude model]] for ''[[Playboy]]'' magazine and was later named their [[Playmate of the Year]]. McCarthy then parlayed her ''Playboy'' fame into a television and film acting career starting as a co-host on the MTV game show ''[[Singled Out]]'', then some eponymous sitcoms, as well as films such as ''[[BASEketball]]'', ''[[Diamonds (1999 film)|Diamonds]]'', ''[[Scream 3]]'', and ''[[Santa Baby (film)|Santa Baby]]''. She is a former co-host of the [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] talk show ''[[The View (U.S. TV series)|The View]]''. McCarthy has written books about [[parenting]] and has become an activist promoting research into environmental causes and [[alternative medicine|alternative medical]] treatments for [[autism]]. She has promoted the idea that [[vaccines cause autism]]{{cite journal |journal= Neurol Today |year=2008 |volume=8 |issue=11 |pages=1, 8 |title= After vaccine–autism case settlement, MDs urged to continue recommending vaccines |author= Fallik D |url=http://www.neurotodayonline.com/pt/re/neurotoday/fulltext.00132985-200806050-00001.htm |doi= 10.1097/01.NT.0000324682.98661.5c}} and that [[Chelation therapy#Autism|chelation therapy]] helped cure her son of autism. Both claims are unsupported by medical consensus, and her son's autism diagnosis has been questioned. McCarthy has been described as "the nation's most prominent purveyor of anti-vaxxer ideology", but she has denied the charge, stating: "I am not anti-vaccine". == Early life == Jennifer Ann McCarthy was born on November 1, 1972 at Little Company of Mary Hospital located in the southwest Chicago suburb of [[Evergreen Park, Illinois]].{{cite web |url=http://www.cookcountyclerk.com/sweethomecookcounty/documents/2007sweethome.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2017-10-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160528132937/http://www.cookcountyclerk.com/sweethomecookcounty/documents/2007sweethome.pdf |archivedate=May 28, 2016 |df=mdy-all }} She was born to a working-class Catholic family, and has Irish, German, and Polish ancestry.{{cite news|author=Sweeney, Meghan|url= http://www.irishcentral.com/ent/And-now-for-the-Worst-Performance-by-an-Irish-American-2780.html |title=Irish-American actors (dis)honored with a Razzie]|work= IrishCentral''|date= March 10, 2009}}{{cite web |url=http://www.starpulse.com/news/index.php/2010/09/28/jenny_mccarthys_genitals_compared_to_r |title=Jenny McCarthy's Genitals Compared To 'Roadkill' – Starpulse.com |publisher=www.starpulse.com |accessdate=October 7, 2010|date= September 28, 2010|quote= I see them talk to the make-up artist and the make-up artist comes walking over and she goes, 'They said they'd never saw anyone as hairy as you their entire life.' I said, 'Well, I'm half Polish!'}} She lived in the [[West Elsdon, Chicago|West Elsdon]] neighborhood of Chicago.{{cite news|last=Linke|first=Denise|title=Trip to Chicago brings back memories|date=April 9, 2016|newspaper=[[Chicago Tribune]]|location=[[Chicago, Illinois]]|accessdate=September 4, 2017|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/suburbs/elgin-courier-news/lifestyles/ct-ecn-donnie-loves-jenny-st-0411-20160408-story.html}} She is the second of four daughters – her sisters are named Lynette, [[Joanne McCarthy|Joanne]], and Amy; actress [[Melissa McCarthy]] is her cousin.{{cite web|url= http://ca.eonline.com/news/true_false_new_emmy_winner_melissa/264647|title= So True? So False? Is New Emmy Winner Melissa McCarthy Really Related to Jenny McCarthy?!|first= Gina|last= Serpe|work= ca.eonline.com|date= 2011-09-19|accessdate= January 2, 2012|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://archive.is/20120709232808/http://ca.eonline.com/news/true_false_new_emmy_winner_melissa/264647|archivedate= July 9, 2012|df= mdy-all}}{{cite web|url=http://www.tvguide.com/celebrities/melissa-mccarthy/bio/190575 |title=Melissa McCarthy Biography|work=TVGuide.com|accessdate= April 29, 2008}} McCarthy's mother, Linda, was a housewife and courtroom custodian, and her father, Dan McCarthy, was a steel mill foreman.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/specials/magazine4/articles/mccarthy.html |work=The New York Times |title=The McCarthy Era |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061223215034/http://www.nytimes.com/specials/magazine4/articles/mccarthy.html |archivedate=December 23, 2006 }}{{cite web|url=http://www.filmreference.com/film/52/Jenny-McCarthy.html |title=Jenny McCarthy Biography (1972– ) |publisher=Film Reference|date= |accessdate=2011-07-18}} As a teenager McCarthy attended [[Mother McAuley Liberal Arts High School]], whose school sweater she donned in the pages of ''Playboy'', and was a cheerleader at both [[Brother Rice High School (Chicago, Illinois)|Brother Rice High School]] and [[St. Laurence High School]],{{cite journal|last1= Austin|first1= Michael |last2= Wehunt |first2=Jennifer |title=Before They Were Famous|journal=[[Chicago (magazine)|Chicago]]|page= 76|date= February 2007|volume= 56| number= 2}} although she has referred to herself as an "outcast" at her school[http://www.usaweekend.com/98_issues/980719/980719talk_mccarthy.html USA WEEKEND Magazine]{{dead link|date=July 2011}} and has stated she was repeatedly bullied by classmates.{{cite news|last=Pinsky|first=Drew|authorlink=Drew Pinsky|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hBfJn0UZ4oI |title=Jenny McCarthy: I was bullied|series=''[[Dr. Drew (TV series)|Dr. Drew]]''|work= [[HLN (TV channel)|HLN]]|date= October 10, 2011}} She spent two years at [[Southern Illinois University]]. == Career == === Modeling and acting === {{Infobox Playboy Playmate | name = Jenny McCarthy | image = | imagesize = | caption = | issue = October 1993 | birth_name = | birth_place = | birth_date = | death_date = | height = {{height|ft=5|in=7}} | weight = {{convert|120|lb|kg|abbr=on}} | preceded = [[Carrie Westcott]] | succeeded = [[Julianna Young]] | pmoy-year = 1994 | pmoy-preceded = [[Anna Nicole Smith]] | pmoy-succeeded = [[Julie Lynn Cialini]] }} In 1993 ''Playboy'' magazine offered McCarthy $20,000 to pose for its October issue. McCarthy became the Playmate of the Month for October 1993. ''Playboy'' publisher [[Hugh Hefner]] cites McCarthy's "wholesome Catholic girl" persona as the unique quality for which she was selected out of 10,000 applicants."Jenny McCarthy" ''[[Biography (TV series)|Biography]]''. [[The Biography Channel]]. December 24, 2007[https://www.nytimes.com/specials/magazine4/articles/mccarthy.html "Heroine Worship: The McCarthy Era"]. ''[[The New York Times Magazine]]'' Her layout emphasized her Catholic upbringing with a schoolgirl theme. According to McCarthy, the pictorial caused an uproar in her Catholic neighborhood, and resulted in her house being pelted with eggs, her sisters being taunted at school, and McCarthy, who counted Catholic nuns among her aunts, being lectured about her future [[damnation]] by those close to her. McCarthy was later made the Playmate of the Year, and was paid a $100,000 salary. In 1994, because of her newfound public attention, McCarthy moved to Los Angeles and, for a time, hosted ''Hot Rocks'', a [[Playboy TV]] show featuring uncensored [[music video]]s.{{Cite news|url=http://abc7.com/archive/8665847/|title=Jenny McCarthy to pose for Playboy again|work=ABC7 Los Angeles|access-date=2018-01-15|language=en}} In 1995, when [[MTV]] chose McCarthy to cohost a new dating show called ''[[Singled Out]]'', she left ''Hot Rocks''. Her job as a host was a success, and ''Playboy'' wanted her to do more modeling. That same year she also appeared at [[WWE|World Wrestling Federation]] (WWF) pay-per-view event [[WrestleMania XI]] as a guest valet for villain [[Shawn Michaels]], who faced heroic [[WWE Championship|WWF Champion]], [[Kevin Nash|Diesel]]. She left after the match with the victor, Diesel. McCarthy returned to World Wrestling Entertainment (WWE, formerly the WWF) on the [[Saturday Night's Main Event results#Saturday Night's Main Event XXXVI|edition of August 2, 2008,]] of ''[[Saturday Night's Main Event]]'' to thank the fans for supporting [[Generation Rescue]], an [[autism]] advocacy organization. In 1996 she landed a small part in the comedy ''[[The Stupids (film)|The Stupids]]''. In 1997 McCarthy launched two shows. The first one was an MTV sketch comedy show ''[[The Jenny McCarthy Show (1997)|The Jenny McCarthy Show]]'', which was sufficiently popular for [[NBC]] to sign her for an eponymous sitcom later that year, ''[[Jenny (TV series)|Jenny]]''. Also in 1997 she appeared on one of two covers for the September issue of ''Playboy'' (the other cover featured [[Pamela Anderson]]). McCarthy also released an autobiography: ''Jen-X: Jenny McCarthy's Open Book''.{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/dp/0060392339|title=Jen-X: Jenny McCarthy's Open Book|accessdate=2010-05-06|publisher=[[Amazon.com]]}} In 1998 McCarthy's first major movie role was alongside [[Trey Parker]] and [[Matt Stone]] in the comedy ''[[BASEketball]]''. The following year, she starred in ''[[Diamonds (1999 film)|Diamonds]]''. In 2000 she had a role in the horror movie ''[[Scream 3]]'', and three years later she [[parodied]] that role in horror film [[Parody|spoof]] ''[[Scary Movie 3]]'' along with fellow Playmate and actress [[Pamela Anderson]]. In 2005, McCarthy produced, wrote, and starred in the movie ''[[Dirty Love (film)|Dirty Love]]'', which was directed by her husband at the time, [[John Asher]]. In March 2006 she was given [[26th Golden Raspberry Awards|Razzie Awards]] for "Worst Actress", "Worst Screenplay", and "Worst Picture" for her work on ''Dirty Love'', which also earned Asher a Razzie for "Worst Director."{{cite web|title=26th Annual Golden Raspberry (Razzie©) Award 'Winners'|url=http://www.razzies.com/history/05winners.asp|author=John Wilson and The Golden Raspberry Award Foundation|year=2006|access-date=August 4, 2008|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080705030031/http://www.razzies.com/history/05winners.asp|archive-date=July 5, 2008|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} In addition to her early TV fame on MTV and her short-lived, self-titled NBC sitcom, McCarthy has guest-starred in a variety of other television shows, including ''[[Stacked]]'', ''[[Charmed]]'', ''[[The Drew Carey Show]]'', ''[[Wings (NBC TV series)|Wings]]'', ''[[Fastlane (TV series)|Fastlane]]'', ''[[Two and a Half Men]]'' and ''[[Just Shoot Me!]]''.{{Citation needed|date=March 2011}} She was the voice of Six in the third season of Canadian computer-animated science fiction cartoon ''[[Tripping the Rift]]''. In 2005 McCarthy hosted a show on [[E!]] called ''Party at the Palms''. The [[reality television|reality show]], which was filmed at [[Palms Casino Resort|The Palms]] Hotel in [[Las Vegas]], featured hotel guests, party goers, and celebrities.{{cite web|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2005/Jun-06-Mon-2005/living/1997484.html|title=Las Vegas Review-Journal|author=|date=|website=Las Vegas Review-Journal|accessdate=May 17, 2017}} McCarthy has continued her work with ''Playboy'' over the years, both as a model and in other capacities. She appeared on the cover of the magazine's January 2005 issue wearing a leopard skin version of the company's iconic [[Playboy bunny|"bunny suit"]] and was featured in a pictorial shot at [[Elvis Presley]]'s [[Graceland]] mansion in that same issue. She was the second woman (following [[Carmen Electra]]) and first former Playmate to become a celebrity photographer for the Playboy Cyber Club, where she photographed model Jennifer Madden.{{Citation needed|date=March 2011}} Her younger sister, Amy McCarthy, also has posed for ''Playboy''. She was Cyber Girl of the Week for September 27, 2004, and Cyber Girl of the Month for January 2005.{{cite web|url=http://www.playboy.com/girls/cybergirls/month/200501/|accessdate=2007-09-18|title=Amy McCarthy|publisher=Playboy.com|date=January 2005|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071011030807/http://www.playboy.com/girls/cybergirls/month/200501/|archivedate=October 11, 2007|df=mdy-all}} In 2007 McCarthy starred in a five-episode online series, called ''[[In the Motherhood]]'', along with [[Chelsea Handler]] and [[Leah Remini]].{{cite web|url=http://www.inthemotherhood.com/ |title=ABC.com – Television Shows & Programming |publisher=Inthemotherhood.com |date= |accessdate=2011-07-18}} The show aired on [[MSN]] and was based on being a mother where users could submit their stories to have it made into real webisodes. She has also appeared in two video games: playing the role of Agent Tanya in the video game ''[[Command and Conquer: Red Alert 3]]'', replacing [[Kari Wührer]], and the fitness video game ''Your Shape Featuring Jenny McCarthy''.{{cite journal|periodical=Playboy|publisher=Playboy Inc.|title=Playmate News|volume=56|date=December 2009|pages=166–167}} On December 31, 2010, McCarthy was a correspondent in [[Times Square]] for [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]]'s ''[[Dick Clark's New Year's Rockin' Eve]]''.{{cite web | url=http://www.parade.com/celebrity/celebrity-parade/2010/1221-jenny-mccarthy-new-years.html | title=Jenny McCarthy: 'I'm Gonna Bring New Year's Eve on Steroids' | publisher=[[Parade (magazine)|Parade]] | date=December 22, 2010 | accessdate=August 15, 2013 | author=Wolf, Jeanne}} She also appeared in the 40th anniversary of ABC's New Year celebration where she kissed a nearby New York City cop.{{cite web|title=Jenny McCarthy locked lips with mystery cop on New Year's Eve|url=http://todayentertainment.today.com/_news/2012/01/02/9894625-jenny-mccarthy-locked-lips-with-mystery-cop-on-new-years-eve?lite|publisher=NBC News Online|accessdate=2013-01-07}} She appeared in the edition of December 31, 2012 of ''New Year's Rockin' Eve'' and kissed a midshipman of the United States Merchant Marine Academy.{{cite news|title=Sealed with a kiss! Jenny McCarthy re-enacts famous VJ Day smooch with one lucky man as she parties in Times Square|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-2255779/Jenny-McCarthys-New-Years-Eve-kiss-Star-enacts-VJ-Day-smooch-lucky-man-Times-Square.html|publisher=Mail Online|accessdate=2013-01-07|location=London|first=Iona|last=Kirby|date=January 1, 2013}} She was the host of season 2 of ''[[Love in the Wild]]'', which aired in the summer of 2012.{{cite web|url=http://www.parade.com/celebrity/news/2012/04/19-jenny-mccarthy.html|title=Jenny McCarthy: 'I'm Taking Baby Steps' with New Romance|accessdate=2012-05-05|date=2012-04-19|work=[[Parade (magazine)|Parade]]|author=Margaret, Mary}} She was on the cover of ''Playboy'' in the August 2012 issue after saying she wanted to pose for it again before her 40th birthday.{{cite web|last=Shira |first=Dahvi |url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20606671,00.html |title=Jenny McCarthy Playboy: Photo of Cover – Jenny McCarthy Naked Picture |publisher=People.com |date=2012-06-25 |accessdate=2014-02-03}} After 17 guest appearances, in July 2013 McCarthy was announced as a new co-host on [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]]'s ''[[The View (U.S. TV series)|The View]]'', replacing former co-host [[Elisabeth Hasselbeck]]. [[Barbara Walters]] praised McCarthy's intelligence, warmth, humor and fresh point of view, and calling her a great addition to the show.{{cite web |title=Jenny McCarthy to replace Elisabeth Hasselbeck on The View |url=http://www.13abc.com/story/22842397/jenny-mccarthy-to-replace-eli |work=[[ABC News]] |date=July 15, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130908024329/http://www.13abc.com/story/22842397/jenny-mccarthy-to-replace-eli |archivedate=September 8, 2013 |df= }}{{cite web| title = Jenny McCarthy officially named 'The View' co-host | url = http://insidetv.ew.com/2013/07/15/jenny-mccarthy-the-view/| last = Hibberd| first = James| date = July 15, 2013| work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]| accessdate = 2013-07-16}} She debuted as a co-host on September 9, 2013. The departures of McCarthy and co-host [[Sherri Shepherd]] from ''The View'' were announced in June 2014.{{cite web|url=http://www.usmagazine.com/celebrity-news/news/sherri-shepherd-and-jenny-mccarthy-leave-the-view-2014266|title=Sherri Shepherd and Jenny McCarthy Leave The View|author=|date=|website=usmagazine.com|accessdate=May 17, 2017}} ''The Wrap'' reported that ABC had decided not to renew McCarthy's contract.{{cite web|url=http://www.thewrap.com/inside-the-view-exits-sherri-shepherd-rejected-abcs-final-offer-jenny-mccarthys-contract-not-renewed/|title=Inside 'The View' Exits: Sherri Shepherd Rejected ABC's Final Offer; Jenny McCarthy's Contract Not Renewed|author=|date=June 27, 2014|website=thewrap.com|accessdate=May 17, 2017}} In an interview with ''Access Hollywood'', McCarthy denied being fired from the show.{{cite web|url=http://www.accesshollywood.com/jenny-mccarthy-i-wasnt-fired-from-the-view-it-was-mutual_article_96617|title=Jenny McCarthy: I Wasn't Fired From 'The View' – It Was 'Mutual'|author=|date=|website=Access Hollywood|accessdate=May 17, 2017}} McCarthy became a [[SiriusXM]] series host of a show called ''Dirty, Sexy, Funny with Jenny McCarthy'' on July 16, 2014.{{cite web|url=https://gma.yahoo.com/jenny-mccarthys-next-career-move-revealed-144608830--abc-news-celebrities.html|title=Jenny McCarthy's Next Career Move Revealed|accessdate=2014-08-12|date=2014-07-14|publisher=[[Good Morning America]]/[[Yahoo!]]|author=Rothman, Michael}} === Public persona === [[File:20050404 Jenny McCarthy.jpg|thumb|McCarthy in April 2005]] McCarthy once modeled for [[Candie's]], a shoe company. In one magazine ad, McCarthy posed on a toilet seat with her underwear near her ankles. Cultural scholar Collin Gifford Brooke wrote that the ad's "[[taboo]] nature" brought it attention, while noting that the ad itself helped to weaken that taboo.{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/?id=ZivAGEvtpDcC&pg=PA136&dq=jenny+mccarthy+candies+toilet |title=Sex in Advertising: Perspectives on the Erotic Appeal |author=Collin Gifford Brooke |chapter=Sex(haustion) Sells: Marketing in a Saturated Mediascape |editor1=Tom Reichert |editor2=Jacqueline Lambiase |publisher=Lawrence Erlbaum Associates |year=2003 |isbn=0-8058-4118-0}} Another Candie's ad depicted McCarthy "passing wind" in a crowded elevator.{{cite web|url=http://www.bnet.com/blog/advertising-business/so-bad-its-good-why-really-awful-ad-campaigns-work-so-well/6627 |title=So Bad It's Good: Why Really Awful Ad Campaigns Work So Well |publisher=BNET |date= |accessdate=2011-07-18}}Boehning, Julie C. Footwear News. July 28, 1997. http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-19632413.html. retrieved July 17, 2011. == Personal life == McCarthy dated manager Ray Manzella from 1994 until 1998 and began dating actor/director [[John Mallory Asher]] late in 1998.{{cite news|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,990114,00.html|title=Jenny Cme Back|accessdate= October 5, 2008 |date= February 1, 1999|work=[[Time (magazine)|TIME]]|author=Orecklin, Michele}} The couple became engaged in January 1999 and married on September 11 of that year. They have a son, Evan Joseph Asher, born on May 18, 2002, who was diagnosed with [[autism]] on May 10, 2005.{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2007/US/09/24/jenny.autism/ |title=Jenny McCarthy: The day I heard my son had autism|date=March 28, 2008 |accessdate=July 17, 2013 |author=McCarthy, Jenny |publisher=[[CNN]]}} McCarthy and Asher divorced in September 2005.{{cite web|url=http://recordssitereviews.com/divorcerecords/john-asher-jenny-mccarthy-divorce.html|title=The John Asher and Jenny McCarthy Divorce|accessdate= October 2, 2011|publisher=recordssitereview.com}} In December 2005, McCarthy began dating actor [[Jim Carrey]]. They did not make their relationship public until June 2006. She announced on ''[[The Ellen DeGeneres Show]]'' on April 2, 2008 that she and Carrey were living together but had no plans to marry, as they did not need a "piece of paper".{{cite web | url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20237480,00.html | title=Jenny McCarthy Doesn't 'Need Piece of Paper to Prove My Love' | accessdate= December 29, 2010| author=Dreben, Jeb | date= November 3, 2008 | publisher=People Magazine (people.com)}} Carrey almost made a mock proposal to McCarthy as a promotion to the film ''[[Yes Man (film)|Yes Man]]'' (2008) for Ellen's Twelve Days of Holidays. In April 2010, McCarthy and Carrey announced that they had split up.{{cite news|url=http://content.usatoday.com/communities/entertainment/post/2010/04/carrey-mccarthy-announce-split/1|work=[[USA Today]]|title=Jim Carrey, Jenny McCarthy announce split|accessdate=April 6, 2010 | date=April 6, 2010|first=Gary|last=Levin}} In July 2013, McCarthy stated that she was dating [[Donnie Wahlberg]].{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/07/13/jenny-mccarthy-donnie-wahlberg_n_3591385.html|title=Jenny McCarthy, Donnie Wahlberg Dating: New Couple Reportedly Spent July 4th Together|accessdate=July 16, 2013 | work=Huffington Post|first=Liat|last=Kornowski|date=July 13, 2013}} On April 16, 2014 McCarthy announced that she and Wahlberg were engaged,{{cite web|last=Tan|first=Michelle|title=Jenny McCarthy Engaged to Donnie Wahlberg|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20807315,00.html|work=People|accessdate=April 16, 2014}} and they wed on August 31, 2014.{{cite news |url=http://www.people.com/article/jenny-mccarthy-donnie-wahlberg-twitter-photo |title=Jenny McCarthy and Donnie Wahlberg Share Their First Newlywed Selfie |first=Michele |last=Corriston |work=[[People (magazine)|People]] |date=September 3, 2014 |accessdate=September 7, 2014}}{{cite news |url=http://abcnews.go.com/Entertainment/exclusive-donnie-wahlberg-talks-love-photography-exciting-wedding/story?id=25235858 |title=Exclusive: Donnie Wahlberg Talks Love of Photography, 'Exciting' Wedding to Jenny McCarthy |work=[[ABC News]] |first=Michael |last=Rothman |date=September 4, 2014 |accessdate=September 7, 2014}}{{cite journal |url=http://www.usmagazine.com/celebrity-news/news/jenny-mccarthy-donnie-wahlberg-wedding-exclusive-pictures-details-201459 |title=Jenny McCarthy, Donnie Wahlberg Wedding: Exclusive Pictures, More Details |first=Stephanie |last=Webber |magazine=[[Us Weekly]] |date=September 5, 2014 |accessdate=September 7, 2014}} ==Activism== === Autism activism and views on vaccines === [[File:Jenny McCarthy Addresses Audience.jpg|thumb|right|upright|McCarthy speaking at the 2008 Ante Up For Autism benefit]] In May 2007, McCarthy announced that her son Evan was diagnosed with [[autism]] in 2005. Before claiming that her son's autism was caused by vaccination, McCarthy wrote that he was gifted, a "crystal child", and she an "[[Indigo children|indigo mom]]".{{cite web|title=Insights of an indigo mom: a mother's awakening |author=McCarthy J |year=2006 |accessdate=April 2, 2009 |url=http://childrenofthenewearth.com/free.php?page=articles_free/mccarthy_jenny/article1 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090402112107/http://childrenofthenewearth.com/free.php?page=articles_free%2Fmccarthy_jenny%2Farticle1 |archivedate=April 2, 2009 |df= }} Evan's disorder began with seizures and his improvement occurred after the seizures were treated, which symptoms experts have noted are more consistent with [[Landau–Kleffner syndrome]], often misdiagnosed as autism.{{cite news|author=Greenfeld KT |url=http://www.time.com/time/nation/article/0,8599,1967796-1,00.html |title=The autism debate: who's afraid of Jenny McCarthy? |work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |date=February 25, 2010 }} [https://web.archive.org/web/20110805041329/http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0%2C9171%2C1968100%2C00.html Archived copy]{{cite journal |journal=Neurol Today |year=2008 |volume=8 |issue=15 |page=3 |title=Fanning the vaccine–autism link |author= Rubin DB |url=http://neurotodayonline.com/pt/re/neurotoday/fulltext.00132985-200808070-00005.htm |doi=10.1097/01.NT.0000335577.64245.34 }} She has denied that her son was misdiagnosed.{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/JennyMcCarthy/status/419393734128975872|title=Stories circulating online, claiming that I said my son Evan may not have autism after all, are blatantly (cont) |publisher=Twitter|author=McCarthy, Jenny|accessdate=October 28, 2014|date=January 4, 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.twitlonger.com/show/n_1rvdf6g|title=@JennyMcCarthy status update|quote=Stories circulating online, claiming that I said my son Evan may not have autism after all, are blatantly inaccurate and completely ridiculous.... The implication that I have changed my position, that my child was not initially diagnosed with autism (and instead may suffer from Landau-Kleffner Syndrome), is both irresponsible and inaccurate...."|publisher=TwitLonger.com|author=McCarthy, Jenny|accessdate=October 28, 2014|date=January 4, 2014}} In a 2014 ''[[Daily Beast]]'' article, she says her son is now 12 and doing okay: "Evan's amazing,... He doesn't meet the diagnostic characteristics for autism. He definitely has quirks and issues from the seizures. He has a little bit of brain damage due to his seizures. He doesn't qualify for any more services, but he does have issues in his school."{{Citation |last=Grove |first=Lloyd |date=October 24, 2014 |title=Jenny McCarthy: I Am Not Anti-Vaccine |work=[[The Daily Beast]] |url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2014/10/24/jenny-mccarthy-i-am-not-anti-vaccine.html |accessdate=October 26, 2014 }} McCarthy served as a spokesperson for [[Talk About Curing Autism]] (TACA) from June 2007 until October 2008.{{cite web|url=http://tacanow.org/jenny/ |title=TACA & Jenny McCarthy |date=October 5, 2008 |accessdate=November 4, 2008 |author=Ackerman L }}{{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} She participated in fundraisers, online chats, and other activities for the [[non-profit organization]] to help families affected by [[autism spectrum]] disorders. Her first fundraiser for TACA, ''Ante Up for Autism'',{{cite web|author=zekedesign.com |url=http://www.anteupforautism.org |title=Taca |publisher=''Ante Up For Autism'' |date= |accessdate=2011-07-18}} was held on October 20, 2007, in [[Irvine, California]]. She is a prominent spokesperson and activist for the [[Generation Rescue]] foundation,{{cite journal|author=Coombes R |title=Vaccine disputes |journal=BMJ |volume=338 |pages=b2435 |year=2009 |pmid=19546136 |doi=10.1136/bmj.b2435 |url=http://www.theoneclickgroup.co.uk/documents/vaccines/Vaccine%20disputes,%20BMJ.pdf |format=PDF |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716055010/http://www.theoneclickgroup.co.uk/documents/vaccines/Vaccine%20disputes%2C%20BMJ.pdf |archivedate=July 16, 2011 |df= }} and serves on its Board of Directors as of January 2011.{{cite web |url= http://www.generationrescue.org/about/leadership |title= Leadership:Board of Directors |publisher= [[Generation Rescue]] |year= 2011 |accessdate= January 7, 2011 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101216022002/http://generationrescue.org/about/leadership |archivedate= December 16, 2010 |df= mdy-all }} McCarthy's book dealing with autism, ''Louder than Words: A Mother's Journey in Healing Autism'', was published September 17, 2007. She stated both in her book and during her appearance on ''[[The Oprah Winfrey Show]]'' that her husband was unable to deal with their son's autism, which led to their divorce. In 2008, she appeared on a ''[[Larry King Live]]'' special dedicated to the subject and argued that [[MMR vaccine controversy|vaccines can trigger autism]].{{cite journal |author=Gross L |title=A broken trust: lessons from the vaccine–autism wars |journal=PLoS Biol |volume=7 |issue=5 |pages=e1000114 |year=2009 |pmid=19478850 |doi=10.1371/journal.pbio.1000114 |url=http://www.plosbiology.org/article/info:doi/10.1371/journal.pbio.1000114 |pmc=2682483 }}{{cite news |url=http://transcripts.cnn.com/TRANSCRIPTS/0804/02/lkl.01.html |title=CNN Larry King Live: Jenny McCarthy's Autism Fight, Aired April 2, 2008 |work= |accessdate= May 11, 2009}} In an April 27, 2010 PBS ''[[Frontline (U.S. TV series)|Frontline]]'' documentary, she was interviewed about the controversy between vaccine opponents and public health experts.{{cite news| url=http://www.boston.com/ae/tv/articles/2010/04/27/measured_doses_of_fact_friction_in_vaccine_war/ | work=The Boston Globe | title=Measured doses of fact, friction in 'Vaccine War' | first=Don | last=Aucoin | date=April 27, 2010}}[https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/vaccines/ "The Vaccine War"], PBS ''[[Frontline (U.S. TV series)|Frontline]]'' documentary, April 27, 2010 In addition to conventional, intensive [[Applied behavior analysis#Efficacy in autism|Applied Behavioral Analysis (ABA) therapy]], McCarthy tried for her son a [[gluten-free]] and [[casein-free diet]], [[hyperbaric oxygen chamber]]s, [[chelation]], [[aromatherapy|aromatherapies]], electromagnetics, spoons rubbed on his body, multivitamin therapy, B-12 shots, and numerous prescription drugs. "Try everything", she advises parents. "It was amazing to watch, over the course of doing this, how certain therapies work for certain kids and they completely don't work for others.... When something didn't work for Evan, I didn't stop. I stopped that treatment, but I didn't stop." McCarthy has stated on talk shows and at rallies that [[chelation therapy]] helped her son recover from autism.{{cite news|last=Rochman|first=Bonnie|title=Jenny McCarthy, Vaccine Expert? A Quarter of Parents Trust Celebrities|url=http://healthland.time.com/2011/04/26/jenny-mccarthy-vaccine-expert-a-quarter-of-parents-trust-celebrities/ |accessdate=May 6, 2011 |newspaper=Time |date=April 26, 2011}} The underlying rationale for chelation, the speculation that [[Thiomersal controversy|mercury in vaccines causes autism]], has been roundly rejected by scientific studies, with the [[National Institute of Mental Health]] concluding that children with autism are unlikely to receive any benefit to balance the risks of heart attack, stroke and cardiac arrest posed by the [[chelation|chelating agent]]s used in the treatment.{{cite journal |journal=Science |year=2008 |volume=321 |issue=5887 |page=326 |title= Stalled trial for autism highlights dilemma of alternative treatments |author=Stokstad E |doi=10.1126/science.321.5887.326 |pmid=18635766}} McCarthy's public presence and vocal activism on the [[vaccination-autism controversy]], led, in 2008, to her being awarded the [[James Randi]] Educational Foundation's [[Pigasus Award]], which is a [[tongue-in-cheek]] award granted for contributions to [[pseudoscience]], for the "Performer Who Has Fooled the Greatest Number of People with the Least Amount of Effort". Randi stated in a video on the JREF's website that he did sympathize with the plight of McCarthy and her child, but admonished her for using her public presence in a way that may discourage parents from having their own children vaccinated.{{cite web |url=http://www.randi.org/site/index.php/jref-news/500-pigasus-awards-for-2008-announced.html |title=Pigasus Awards for 2008 Announced |accessdate=April 16, 2010 |date=April 1, 2009 |publisher=[[James Randi Educational Foundation]]}} McCarthy's claims that vaccines cause autism are not supported by any medical evidence, and the original paper by [[Andrew Wakefield]] that formed the basis for the claims (and for whose book McCarthy wrote a foreword){{cite news |url= http://healthland.time.com/2011/01/06/study-linking-vaccines-to-autism-is-fraudulent/ |title= Study linking vaccines to autism is 'fraudulent' |work= [[Time (magazine)|Time]] |date= January 6, 2011 |accessdate= January 7, 2011}} was based on manipulated data and fraudulent research.{{cite journal |year= 2011 |doi= 10.1136/bmj.c7452 |pages= c7452 |volume= 342|title= Wakefield's article linking MMR vaccine and autism was fraudulent |vauthors=Godlee F, Smith J, Marcovitch H |journal = [[BMJ]] |url=http://www.bmj.com/content/342/bmj.c7452.full |pmid=21209060}}{{cite journal | title=How the case against the MMR vaccine was fixed| author=Deer B| journal=BMJ| year=2011| volume=342| pages=c5347 | pmid=21209059| url=http://www.bmj.com/content/342/bmj.c5347.full |doi= 10.1136/bmj.c5347}}{{cite news |url= https://www.npr.org/2011/01/05/132692497/journal-study-linking-vaccine-to-autism-was-fraud |publisher=[[NPR]] | agency= Associated Press |title= Study linking vaccine to autism was fraud |date= January 5, 2011 |accessdate= January 6, 2011 |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110107085338/http://www.npr.org/2011/01/05/132692497/journal-study-linking-vaccine-to-autism-was-fraud |archivedate= 2011-01-07}}{{cite news |publisher=[[CNN]] |title= Retracted autism study an 'elaborate fraud,' British journal finds |url= http://edition.cnn.com/2011/HEALTH/01/05/autism.vaccines/index.html |date=January 6, 2011 |accessdate=January 6, 2011| location=Atlanta}} ''The [[BMJ]]'' published a 2011 article by journalist [[Brian Deer]], based on information uncovered by [[Freedom of Information legislation]] after the British [[General Medical Council]] (GMC) inquiry into allegations of [[Scientific misconduct|misconduct]] against Wakefield that led to him being struck off from the medical register (unable to practice medicine in the UK) and his articles retracted, stating that Wakefield had planned a venture to profit from the [[MMR vaccine]] scare.{{cite journal |journal= BMJ |date= January 11, 2011 |pages= c5258|volume= 342|doi= 10.1136/bmj.c5258 |title= How the vaccine crisis was meant to make money |author=Deer B |url= http://www.bmj.com/content/342/bmj.c5258.full |pmid=21224310}}{{cite news|url= http://voices.washingtonpost.com/checkup/2011/01/wakefield_tried_to_capitalize.html | title= Wakefield tried to capitalize on autism-vaccine link, report says |author= Stein, Rob |date= January 11, 2011|work= The Washington Post |accessdate= January 12, 2011}}{{cite news |url=http://www.cnn.com/2011/HEALTH/01/11/autism.vaccines/?hpt=Sbin |title= Vaccine study's author held related patent, medical journal reports| publisher=[[CNN]] |date= January 11, 2011 |accessdate= January 12, 2011 }}{{cite web |url= http://www.webmd.com/brain/autism/news/20110111/mmr-doctor-planned-make-millions-journal-claims |title= MMR Doctor 'Planned to Make Millions,' Journal Claims |author= Russell, Peter |work=[[WebMD]] |date= January 11, 2011 |accessdate= January 12, 2011 }} [[Generation Rescue]] issued a statement that the "media circus" following the revelation of Wakefield's fraud and manipulation of data was "much ado about nothing",{{cite web|url= http://www.generationrescue.org/ |title= Jenny McCarthy's Generation Rescue | publisher=[[Generation Rescue]] |accessdate= January 6, 2011}} which led ''[[USA Today]]'' to report that McCarthy had "taken a beating on Twitter".{{cite news |url=http://content.usatoday.com/communities/entertainment/post/2011/01/jenny-mccarthy-under-fire-on-twitter-/1 |work= [[USA Today]] |date= January 6, 2011 |accessdate= January 7, 2011 |title= Jenny McCarthy under fire on Twitter |first=Gary |last=Levin}} [[Mary Elizabeth Williams]] responded to Generation Rescue's statement:
It's high time the woman who once said that "I do believe sadly it's going to take some diseases coming back to realize that we need to change and develop vaccines that are safe" took a step back and reconsidered the merits of that increasingly crackpot stance. And it's time she acknowledged that clinging to research that's been deemed patently fraudulent does not make one a "mother warrior." It makes her a menace.{{cite web |url= http://www.salon.com/life/feature/2011/01/06/jenny_mccarthy_autism_debate/ |author= Williams, Mary Elizabeth |title= Jenny McCarthy's autism fight grows more misguided |date= January 6, 2011 |accessdate= January 7, 2011 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110110132939/http://www.salon.com/life/feature/2011/01/06/jenny_mccarthy_autism_debate |archivedate= January 10, 2011 |df= mdy-all }}
In January 2011, McCarthy defended Wakefield, saying that he had listened to parents, reported what they said, and recommended further investigation:
Since when is repeating the words of parents and recommending further investigation a crime? As I've learned, the answer is whenever someone questions the safety of any vaccines. For some reason, parents aren't being told that this "new" information about Dr. Wakefield isn't a medical report, but merely the allegations of a single British journalist named Brian Deer.{{cite news |url= http://www.huffingtonpost.com/jenny-mccarthy/vaccine-autism-debate_b_806857.html |author = McCarthy, Jenny | title= Jenny McCarthy: In the Vaccine-Autism Debate, What Can Parents Believe? |date= January 10, 2011 |work=[[Huffington Post]] |accessdate= January 12, 2011}}
Having written three books on the subject after her son was diagnosed with the syndrome, "by dint of sheer energy and celebrity, McCarthy became the nation's most prominent purveyor of anti-vaxxer ideology", and has reiterated that she is not against vaccines. In an earlier October 2013 interview for ''[[TV Guide]]'', McCarthy is quoted as saying:
It's been three years now since I've even talked about autism or vaccines — I was taken aback when people freaked out that I was going to come on ''The View'' and preach.... I will clarify my stance, which is still the same: That parents are in charge. Space it out, slow it down and do your homework. But I am not at all against vaccines.Ratledge, Ingela. [http://www.tvguide.com/News/Jenny-McCarthy-View-1071940.aspx A Day Out with ''The View's'' Jenny McCarthy]. ''[[TV Guide]]'', October 10, 2013
[[Jeffrey Kluger]], senior writer at ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' Magazine, has criticized McCarthy several times. In an open letter article referring to their past conflicts, he chided her and did not accept her denials:
Jenny, as outbreaks of measles, mumps and whooping cough continue to appear in the U.S.—most the result of parents refusing to vaccinate their children because of the scare stories passed around by anti-vaxxers like you—it's just too late to play cute with the things you've said. You are either floridly, loudly, uninformedly antivaccine or you are the most grievously misunderstood celebrity of the modern era. Science almost always prefers the simple answer, because that's the one that's usually correct. Your quote trail is far too long—and you have been far too wrong—for the truth not to be obvious.{{Citation|last=Kluger|first=Jeffrey|title=''"That Moment When You Must Have a Word With Jenny McCarthy"''|date=April 12, 2014|url=http://time.com/60416/jenny-mccarthy-anti-vaccine-whitewash/|publisher=''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]''|accessdate=October 26, 2014}}
One month later in May 2014, McCarthy published an opinion-editorial addressing her position on vaccines, which specifically mentions Kluger:
I am not "anti-vaccine." This is not a change in my stance nor is it a new position that I have recently adopted. For years, I have repeatedly stated that I am, in fact, "pro-vaccine" and for years I have been wrongly branded as "anti-vaccine." [...] Blatantly inaccurate blog posts about my position have been accepted as truth by the public at large as well as media outlets (legitimate and otherwise), who have taken those false stories and repeatedly turned them into headlines.{{Citation |last=McCarthy |first=Jenny |date=May 14, 2014 |title=The Gray Area on Vaccines |work=[[Chicago Sun-Times]] |url=http://chicago.suntimes.com/uncategorized/7/71/195868/jenny-mccarthy-the-gray-area-on-vaccines/ |accessdate=January 7, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141226002443/http://chicago.suntimes.com/uncategorized/7/71/195868/jenny-mccarthy-the-gray-area-on-vaccines/ |archivedate=December 26, 2014 |df=mdy-all }}
During a subsequent ''[[Daily Beast]]'' interview she stated:
I am not anti-vaccine,... I'm in this gray zone of, I think everyone should be aware and educate yourself and ask questions. And if your kid is having a problem, ask your doctor for an alternative way of doing the shots.... The ironic thing is my position has always remained the same. People just never listened to it.
In a 2015 ''[[Medscape]]'' article about celebrities who "speak out about illness", [[Jeffrey A. Lieberman]] criticized McCarthy and her views on vaccines, [[thimerosal]], and autism. He had this to say about her influence: "She has no idea what she is talking about. What she said is misleading and harmful, and the measles outbreak is a clear indication of the response to the spread of such pseudoscientific myths."{{Citation |last=Lieberman |first=Jeffrey |date=March 12, 2015 |title=Should Celebrities Speak Out About Illness? |work=[[Medscape]] |url=http://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/841049 |accessdate=March 17, 2015 }} === Objections to appointment on ''The View'' === McCarthy's appointment to ''The View'' called forth many protests. Amy Pisani of [[Every Child By Two]] stated of McCarthy's anti-vaccination stance, in a letter to ''The View'''s [[Barbara Walters]] and [[Bill Geddie]], that McCarthy's "unfounded claims that vaccines cause autism have been one of the greatest impediments to public health in recent decades", and that McCarthy's assertions "[have] spread fear among young parents, which has led to an increased number of children who have not received life-saving vaccines."{{cite news |url = https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/tv/2013/07/15/abc-the-view-jenny-mccarthy-barbara-walters/2517659/ |title = Jenny McCarthy joins 'The View'|last = Levin| first = Gary|work=[[USA Today]]| date = July 15, 2013| accessdate = 2013-07-16}} [[James Poniewozik]], a television critic for ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' magazine, criticized McCarthy's addition to the series and Walters' endorsement of McCarthy, arguing that ''The View'' is largely aimed at parents, on whom the public health system is dependent, and that the credibility that McCarthy's hiring will give her will endanger the public. Poniewozik argued that McCarthy's views, which might be brought up in discussions with the other hosts, would have the effect of framing the issue of whether vaccines cause autism as a matter of opinion, rather than a firmly refuted idea.{{cite news| title = Viruses Don't Care About Your View: Why ABC Shouldn't Have Hired Jenny McCarthy| url = http://entertainment.time.com/2013/07/15/viruses-dont-care-about-your-view-why-abc-shouldnt-have-hired-jenny-mccarthy/| last = Poniewozik| first = James| work=[[Time (magazine)|TIME]] | date = July 15, 2013}} David Freeman, senior science editor for ''[[The Huffington Post]]'', wrote about the concerns of [[Bill Nye]], who stated: "I believe Ms. McCarthy's views will be discredited."{{cite news| title = Bill Nye: Jenny McCarthy's Errant Views On Childhood Vaccines May Be Discredited On 'The View'| url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/07/15/bill-nye-jenny-mccarthy-childhood-vaccines-autism-the-view_n_3600666.html| last = Freeman| first = David| work=[[The Huffington Post]] | date = July 15, 2013}} [[Alex Pareene]] also protested and published a letter to ABC in ''[[Salon Magazine]]'', entitled "Anti-vaccine conspiracist and 'View' co-host Jenny McCarthy isn't just quirky—she spreads lies that hurt people."{{cite web| title = Dear ABC: Putting Jenny McCarthy on "The View" will kill children. Anti-vaccine conspiracist and "View" co-host Jenny McCarthy isn't just quirky – she spreads lies that hurt people| url = http://www.salon.com/2013/07/16/dear_abc_putting_jenny_mccarthy_on_the_view_will_kill_children/| last = Pareene| first = Alex | work=[[Salon Magazine]]| date = July 16, 2013}} [[Michael Specter]], writing in ''[[The New Yorker]]'', stated:
Jenny McCarthy... will be the show's first co-host whose dangerous views on childhood vaccination may—if only indirectly—have contributed to the sickness and death of people throughout the Western world. McCarthy, who is savvy, telegenic, and pulchritudinous, is also the person most visibly associated with the deadly and authoritatively discredited anti-vaccine movement in the United States.{{cite web| title = Jenny McCarthy's Dangerous Views| url = http://www.newyorker.com/online/blogs/elements/2013/07/jenny-mccarthys-dangerous-views.html|last = Specter| first = Michael| work=[[The New Yorker]]| date = July 16, 2013}}
[[Brendan Nyhan]], writing in ''[[Columbia Journalism Review]]'', commented: "ABC's announcement yesterday that actress/comedian Jenny McCarthy will become a co-host of ''The View'' brought forth a torrent of condemnation from doctors, science journalists, opinion writers, and even entertainment commentators who oppose giving the anti-vaccine activist a high-profile platform to spread misinformation." After an extensive review of news coverage of the hiring, Nyhan concluded that "[t]here is no perfect way to cover McCarthy's hiring, of course, but giving 'balanced' coverage to fringe beliefs is the worst approach to covering misinformation."{{cite web| title = When 'he said,' 'she said' is dangerous. Media errs in giving "balanced" coverage to McCarthy's discredited views.| url = http://www.cjr.org/united_states_project/media_errs_giving_balanced_coverage_to_jenny_mccarthys_discredited_views.php?page=all | last = Nyhan| first = Brendan| work=[[Columbia Journalism Review]]| date = July 16, 2013}} [[Toronto Public Health]] officially denounced the appointment and "launched a Twitter campaign to get ... McCarthy fired from the ABC show ''The View''", tweeting "Jenny McCarthy's anti-vaccine views = misinformation. Please ask ''The View'' to change their mind", and "Jenny McCarthy cites fraudulent research on vaccines & it's irresponsible to provide her with ''The View'' platform."{{cite news|url=https://www.thestar.com/news/city_hall/2013/07/22/jenny_mccarthy_in_the_crosshairs_toronto_public_health_takes_aim.html|title=Jenny McCarthy in the crosshairs: Toronto Public Health takes aim|last=Dale|first=Daniel|date=July 22, 2013|work=[[Toronto Star]]|access-date=|via=}} [[Katrina vanden Heuvel]], member of the [[Council on Foreign Relations]] and Editor of ''[[The Nation]]'', objected to the appointment and wrote about "Jenny McCarthy's Vaccination Fear-Mongering and the Cult of False Equivalence":
One of the most prominent promoters of this falsehood [that vaccines cause autism] is actress Jenny McCarthy, who was recently named as Elisabeth Hasselbeck's replacement on ABC's hit daytime talk-show, ''The View''. Once she's on air, it will be difficult to prevent her from advocating for the anti-vaccine movement. And the mere act of hiring her would seem to credit her as a reliable source....By giving science deniers a public forum, media outlets implicitly condone their claims as legitimate....False equivalency is one of journalism's great pitfalls, and in an effort to achieve "balance", reporters often obscure the truth. What's the merit in "he said, she said" reporting when he says the world is round and she insists it is flat. Indeed, there is an enormous cost to society when the truth could save lives.{{cite web| title = Jenny McCarthy's Vaccination Fear-Mongering and the Cult of False Equivalence| url = http://www.thenation.com/blog/175388/jenny-mccarthys-vaccination-fear-mongering-and-cult-false-equivalence| last = vanden Heuvel| first = Katrina| work=[[The Nation]]| date = July 22, 2013}}
McCarthy responded to the criticism during her media tour to promote ''The View''. Appearing on ''[[The Howard Stern Show]]'', where Stern praised her for landing such a "legitimate job", McCarthy explained that she is not anti-vaccine, but rather she opposes too many vaccines in one sitting because that, she said, causes "[[immune dysregulation]]", which she said can cause autism.{{cite news|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DpnER2gPQDE |work=The Howard Stern Show|title=Jenny McCarthy Interview |date=Sep 23, 2013}} == Publications == *''Jen-X: Jenny McCarthy's Open Book'', an autobiography ([[Harpercollins]] November 1997, {{ISBN|978-0-06-039233-8}}). *''Belly Laughs: The Naked Truth about Pregnancy and Childbirth'' (DaCapo Press, December 13, 2005, {{ISBN|978-0-7382-0949-4}}) *''Baby Laughs: The Naked Truth about the First Year of Mommyhood'' (Plume, April 4, 2006, {{ISBN|978-0-525-94883-4}}) *''Life Laughs: The Naked Truth about Motherhood, Marriage, and Moving On'' (Plume, March 27, 2007, {{ISBN|978-0-525-94947-3}}) *''Louder than Words: A Mother's Journey in Healing Autism'' (Plume, September 17, 2007, {{ISBN|978-0-525-95011-0}}) *''[[Mother Warriors|Mother Warriors: A Nation of Parents Healing Autism Against All Odds]]'' (Plume, September 23, 2008, {{ISBN|978-0-525-95069-1}}) *''Healing and Preventing Autism'' Co-written with Dr. Jerry Kartzinel. ([[Dutton Adult]], March 31, 2009, {{ISBN|978-0-525-95103-2}}) *''Love, Lust & Faking It: The Naked Truth About Sex, Lies, and True Romance'' (Harper, September 28, 2010, {{ISBN|978-0062012982}}) *''Bad Habits: Confessions of a Recovering Catholic'' (Hyperion, October 2, 2012, {{ISBN|0060392339}}), == Filmography == {| class="wikitable" |- ! Year !! Title !! Role !! Notes |- | 1995 || ''[[Things to Do in Denver When You're Dead]]'' || Blonde Nurse || |- | 1996 || ''[[The Stupids (film)|The Stupids]]'' || Glamorous Actress || |- | 1998 || ''[[BASEketball]]'' || Yvette Denslow || |- | 1999 || ''[[Diamonds (1999 film)|Diamonds]]'' || Sugar || |- |rowspan="2"| 2000 || ''[[Scream 3]]'' || Sarah Darling || |- | ''[[Python (film)|Python]]'' || Francesca Garibaldi || made for TV |- | 2001 || ''Thank Heaven'' || Julia || |- | 2002 || ''[[Crazy Little Thing]]'' || Whitney Ann Barnsley || |- | 2003 || ''[[Scary Movie 3]]'' || Katie Embry || |- | 2005 || ''[[Dirty Love (film)|Dirty Love]]'' || Rebecca Sommers || |- |rowspan="3"| 2006 || ''[[Legends Cup (LFL)|Lingerie Bowl]]'' || — || made for TV |- | ''[[John Tucker Must Die]]'' || Lori Spencer || |- | ''[[Santa Baby (film)|Santa Baby]]'' || Mary Class/Mary Claus || made for TV |- |rowspan="2"| 2008 || ''[[Wieners (film)|Wieners]]'' || Ms. Isaac || |- | ''[[Witless Protection]]'' || Connie || |- | 2009 || ''[[Santa Baby 2: Christmas Maybe]]'' || Mary Class/Mary Claus || made for TV |- | 2011 || ''[[A Turtle's Tale: Sammy's Adventures]]'' || Shelly || voice |- | 2015 || ''[[Tooken (film)|Tooken]]'' || As herself || |} === Television work === {| class="wikitable" |- !
